post.title: What's On Your "Bucket List" Or What Are Some Bucket List Ideas Worth Considering?

body:
you know, I've felt that before, but life really did get better for me

and worse in other ways

but, I decided for myself that instead of giving up on things (within reason), I would just give certain things a shot because we're only here for so long

so, if you have something good you're attempting, I'd say just attempt those few little things. There is an over-glamorization of "success" today, but I have seen a lot of "successful" people fail for even decades before they "made it big" - I've seen so many "behind the scenes" on "successful" people that really puts more of their struggle and "success" in perspective (the losses they've had, failures, broken bones, whatever)

Life doesn't have to be perfect, you just have to give it your best shot and should aim to be a perfectly good person even if you fail in trying to do good

I think that's to me a Christian message that has really gotten lost - when I think of Christianity, I think of the Christians who lost their lives, or Jesus who was abandoned by friends and all that

This year can especially feel weird for some people

Something that was always inspiring for me too was, if you watched skateboarders how many times they would fall and fall and keep trying until they would finally make their trick (I tried to find a video, but maybe you can look it up) - it's a good example of persistence in action, and shows how failure is very much part of the struggle in life

I wish you a Merry Christmas and good luck on whatever you've failed on

![](https://media.giphy.com/media/3oEjHPUyNPSIp3anZu/100w.gif)

body:
You haven’t lost till you stop trying fren God bless and good luck it’s a tough world out there.

On a philosophical note I encourage you to write down ten things you are grateful for each day, this will make you realise how much you have worth celebrating and reprogram your mind towards an attitude of abundance which will in turn make you richer Matthew 25:29

post.title: What's On Your "Bucket List" Or What Are Some Bucket List Ideas Worth Considering?

body:
ha, well when you put it that way I can understand rejecting it

another site suggested creating a "life plan", since it's the end of the year I was thinking of the things I would like to do in life

I guess I think of there being "essential" life goals and "take it or leave it" ones

Most things are probably "take it or leave it" to me, but what are the few things that we feel like we need to do, and once we do them, we can "die happy"?

or, what do we feel like a life purpose or mission is, which once we achieve, we can feel like we "did our job"?

ha, well when you put it that way I can understand rejecting it

another site suggested creating a "life plan", since it's the end of the year I was thinking of the things I would like to do in life

I guess I think of there being "essential" life goals and "take it or leave it" ones

Most things are probably "take it or leave it" to me, but what are the few things that we feel like we need to do, and once we do them, we can "die happy"?

or, what do we feel like a life purpose or mission is, which once we achieve, we can feel like we "did our job"?

body:
> shrug it off and just be happy right here and now.

lol I wish

> Also people you think seem perfect are also full of insecurity doubts and existential dread

Don't think I'm not too. The difference is they are at least capable enough to do some fun things, and I'm not, all I can do is just sit here failing and watching them do everything right just automatically. I'm not a normal person, the problem is I am one of those people myself, but I don't even get to have the results.

> hardships make us stronger.

In this case it's obviously only hindering me, since the people who have it easy are light years ahead of me almost instantly, even if I've been at something for a really long time. So I doubt this is one of those things that makes me stronger.

post.title: What's On Your "Bucket List" Or What Are Some Bucket List Ideas Worth Considering?

body: I think writing a book is an *okay* goal. What I mean is that with enough simple discipline, most anybody can bang out enough words on a keyboard to fill up a book's worth of content. Now, expecting people to read it or for it to be published is another thing **entirely**. To say nothing of talent and experience, developing the level of writing skill that actually makes people want to read what you have to say in a fluent, cogent, and entertaining manner takes many years of hard work; not something most people are capable of or are willing to do.

post.title: What's On Your "Bucket List" Or What Are Some Bucket List Ideas Worth Considering?

body:
Agree with that 100%. I'd like the patience to write a book front to back, but I'm not delusional enough to think it would get published.

I'd disagree with your assessment of it being an 'okay' goal though - writing a book is hard and most people don't do it - it's a good goal to have, even if it's only something to check off the bucket list.
